comment.narrative: Judicial staff are too few, especially women and are lacking in qualification. Somalis, especially women, remain unequal before the law. Legal traininng, including judge's training, is available throughout Somalia. Bar associations are in place in SOuth Central, Somaliland and Puntland. No UNDP supported legal clinics in South Central, but legal aid centres run by NGOs exist in some cases. 1 legal clinic in Somaliland and 1 legal aid centre in Puntland. Poor awareness of human rights and mechanisms for redress.

comment.narrative: Results from Y@R and Y4C I and II.

Output 2.1: Youth and children are identified as per the agreed criteria for selection in the target districts. output 2.2 Systems (for registration) and services (case management, psycho-social testing) for rehabilitation is implemented
- 380 youth are identified - 4 centers are fully staffed and prepared for implementation

90 youth beneficiaries were identified and selected into the programme, In the district of Bosaso, from 16 villages and 4 IDP camps in Bosaso. The Beneficiaries are benefiting from social rehabilitation programme, have been constantly mentored and provided incentives for lunch and transport.
Two caseloads of 80 each (160 participants, 50% girls) have been identified and selected into the programme from 8 districts in Mogadishu. The beneficiaries are benefiting from social rehabilitation programme, have been constantly mentored and provided incentives for lunch and transport

Output 2.1: Social and civic development and rehabilitation is facilitated and supported for 380 adult youth (to include a minimum 30% women) in 4 Resource Centres for Peace with special focus on crime prevention.
At least 95% of youth registered (380, 30% females) have successfully graduated from social rehabilitation component.

- 380 adults (172 Women, 208 Men) were provided with social rehabilitation packages which included theoretical and practical coursework in the areas of social skills and building community cohesion, peacebuilding, and governance and rule of law.
- Out of 380 (173 Women, 207 Men) registered youth, 364 (173Women ,191 men) successfully completed and graduated from the programme.

Formulation of Renewable Energy Project document finalised. description.narrative: Number of Land Use Policies and implementation roadmaps developed that support sustainable Natural Resources Management

comment.narrative: Land use policies and proper enforcement mechanisms on land-use do not exist in all zones of Somalia. This has led to conflicts over natural resources and exacerbated tensions between grazing nomadic pastoralists and sedentary agro-pastoralists. Rural populations are also using land in an ad-hoc manner, cutting trees to produce charcoal and encroaching on grazing lands.

1. One Land Use Policy for at least one zone developed. 2. A gender-sensitive climate compatible National Development Plan (2017-19) finalised 3. At least 300 women trained in adaptation technologies as a foundation for starting sustainable technology marketing enterprises 4. One Project board meeting held.

1. At the national level, Somalia is covered under Regional Climate Change Strategy for the member states of Intergovernmental Agency for Development (IGAD) with support from the UNDP/GEF/LDCF Project. IGAD Regional Climate Change Strategy sets the framework for the National Climate Change Policy for Somalia being formulated by the UNDP/GEF/LDCF Project. The national land policy draft finalized in Somaliland and its review at regional and district level completed. Puntland Land Policy formulation is still ongoing with MoEWT. 2. National Disaster Management Policy to be initiated after the formulation of National Climate Change Policy which is currently under initiation stage and anticipation is to have it completed by the end of 2017. In addition, 2 existing disaster management policies (Somaliland and Puntland) have been updated while the one for South Central to be part of 2017 LOA with Somali Disaster Management Agency (SoDMA)
3.A total of 280 women (160-Somaliland and 120-Puntland) have been trained on adaptation technologies and benefited upscaling activities i.e. fodder production, reforestation -water harvesting .and small scale business cooperatives.
4. Two project Board Meeting were conducted in October and December 2016 with participants from the Federal Government and regional member States key sector ministries. Key Decisions from the meetings were as follows: a. Project Board Meeting -28th October 2016: • Quarterly Progress Report for the quarter ending 30 September 2016 to be shared with participants of the Project Board Meeting • Mid-term evaluation of the project should focus on whether the investments under this project have brought positive changes to the lives of the people • The impacts of the training and policies should be assessed and any recommendations for future improvements should help in revising the project logic • Project should also look into possibilities of expanding the focus according to new administrative realities in Somali

1. Land Use Policy for at least one zone developed. 2. National Disaster Management Policy developed and at least 2 existing plans/policies are updated to address climate risks. 3. National climate change policy is developed including a fund mobilization strategy to raise public and private financing earmarked for climate change adaptation in all zones. 4. A gender-sensitive climate compatible National Development Plan (2017-19) finalised 5. Design and construction of two 50,000 m3 earth dams in Puntland and Somaliland, rehabilitation of 4 dams in South Central, 6, 5 and 8 water diversions constructed in Puntland, Somaliland and South Central respectively, rehabilitation of 4 canals in South Central and rehabilitation of 4 boreholes in South Central 6. At least 200 ha of forest reforested. 7. 8 Agro-Pastoral Field Schools (APFS) established (2 in each district) with 200 direct beneficiaries per APFS (30% women) 8. One (1) gender-sensitive plan developed by each District Disaster Management Committee to be created (with women representation) in the eight target districts (8 plans total) 9. At least 100 women in the four target districts in Southern Central Regions (Guriel, Balanbale, Afgoye, and Jowhar) trained in adaptation technologies as a foundation for starting sustainable technology marketing enterprises

1. Somaliland Land Use Policy completed. 2. National Disaster Management Policy was developed and finalised by Somalia Disaster Management Agency (SODMA). In Somaliland, A disaster management strategy was developed for NERAD while HADMA of Puntland has finalised its disaster management strategy. 3. 60% of the National Climate Change Policy Draft is completed. Also, the Somalia Climate Change Report with loss and Damage, and Adaptation Finance Instruments Chapters have been finalised. 4. Accomplished in previous quarter 5. Somaliland: 95% completion for the Construction work of the 2 earth dams (50,000m3) at Eil-Afweyn and Baligubadle districts. With good rainfall season, over 6000HHs in the 2 districts and surrounding villages will benefit from earth dam infrastructures 90% completion for 70 Berkads rehabilitation. The traditional water reservious will improve the access of a clean water for nearly 16,000HHs (3000HHs-Haaji Salah, 400HHs-Durugsi, 2500HHs-Balidhiig, and 6000HHs-Sanaag drought affected HHs), additionally 4 water diversions competed, and 4 are ongoing. Puntland: construction of 3 new water diversions completed and 4 ongoing. Also, Feasibility studies for 4 earth dams and selection of 14 berkeds rehabilitation were achieved, BOQ, and detail Designs completed, and reviewed by UNDP. South Central: The project has handed over 5 infrastructure sites in two districts (Jowhar-Hir-Shabelle, and Afgooye-South West States) on 26th August 2017, Whereas, 4 sites in Balanbale and Guriel districts are pending for hand over due to suspension from Ministry of Environment of Galmudug state. overall progress, 2 canals in Jowhar (Kafunji, and Bukurale) and Kafunji Water catchments were completed, while Afgooye canal (Irdoole) and Water catchment (Irdoole) are at finalisation stage. 6. Puntland: Afforestation and reseeding of 70 ha in Libaho and Salama villages under Dangorayo district are on-going. Central Somalia: Project has considered other options to implement

comment.narrative:
PIP:
Activity 1: - 2015: While there is large political will, diverging opinions exist and broad-based political and civil agreements have not yet been fully realized. - 2016: Reconciliation process towards state formation has been undertaken in ISWA, GIA and IJA. Hiraan and Middle Shabelle reconciliation process is to be initiated.
Activity 2: - 2015: Establishment Act for the BFC drafted and tabled for parliament’s review and approval. No Commissioners in place; to be appointed after the Act is passed. - 2016: Establishment act for the BFC approved and the commission established.
Activity 3: - 2015: No baseline figures exist on the target population receiving good governance and federalism messages in the IRAs; No conferences conducted in the IRAs on federalism. - 2016: No clear or ad hoc information campaign available on federalism process.
Activity 4: - 2015: Department specifically in charge of federal affairs exists within the Ministry, but with insufficient capacity, and an interim administration does not exist; ad hoc support to MoIFA; MoIFA staff have limited knowledge on federalism and management; ad hoc consultative meetings organized, inclusive of PSG 1 regions. - 2016: Department specifically in charge of federal affairs exists within the Ministry, but with insufficient capacity to facilitate federalism.
Activity 5: - 2015: Short term or ad hoc support available to the emerging states; ad hoc/no training received by the IRAs officials; no office rehabilitated (only in IJA provided by SSF). - 2016: Short term or ad hoc support available to the emerging states. There is no medium term support strategy towards IRAs support.

Weak existing capacity, as evidenced by a recent Government Institutions Capacity Assessment (GICA) conducted by USAID/ Chemonics in November 2014 of MoIFA

Output 5: 5.4: State planning process initiated in April 2016 for ISWA and GIA; no public engagement as of yet

description.narrative: 2016 1)The extent to which the NIEC's institutional capacity is developed 2) Number of inclusive stakeholder engagement and public outreach programmes planned and implemented, including gender mainstreaming

comment.narrative: The 20122 Federal Parliament was selected through a political process by 135 designated clan Elders. No electoral capacity in place at the Federal Level in Somalia before 2015. (No Electoral Law, NIEC Law approved in Feb 2015; NIEC established in July 2015)

1) An electoral process is held for the election of a new Federal Parliament. 2) The legal framework for universal elections is being developed 3) Institutional capacity of the NIEC is being developed
Quarter 3 2016 1) The NIEC is operational and initial institutional capacity in place 2) Public is informed and stakeholders are engaged in the 2016 process according to plan

1) Key support included developing guiding principles and possible measures to ensure and enhance transparency, minimum quota for female representation in both houses, support to draft codes of conduct, as well as projections with regard to logistical and budgetary requirements. The Electoral Support Joint Programme further assisted the FIEIT with the planning of the electoral budget and funding discussions with donor partners. Together with senior representatives of UNSOM and UNDP, discussions were held at the highest level of the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) on the budget, the Government’s contribution, and the financial mechanism to collect and manage the candidates’ registration fees. 2) As part of the 2020 Roadmap regarding the preparation of universal elections, the Joint Programme has been discussing with the NIEC and MOIFA how to initiate the first conceptual steps towards the development of the Electoral Law in an inclusive and consultative manner. To facilitate research that will inform the development of a draft Electoral Law, the Joint Programme supported the compilation of a “Compendium of Electoral Legislation of Somalia (1953-1969)” comprising 12 laws in English, including 6 translated from Italian into English, which has been shared with MOIFA. Translation of the Compendium into Somali has commenced to be completed in the next quarter. 3) Strengthening the foundation of the preparations for the 2020 elections, the NIEC recruited in July an ‘acting’ Secretary-General (Chief Electoral Officer), together with the first phase of its Secretariat staff, including national advisors supported by the Joint Programme. In this respect, the Joint Programme provided in August a finance training for the newly recruited NIEC Operations staff, to strengthen their understanding of procurement processes, finance and assets management. The Joint Programme also conducted a session focusing on a capacity development plan for the Secretariat. On 15 August, the Joi

1. The NIEC is operational and initial institutional capacity in place 2. MOIFA takes the lead in coordinating the development of the electoral law 3. Review of the Political Party Law and on the formulation of the electoral lexicon 4. Lexicon is finalized 5. Electoral process concluded as planned and lead to the establishment of a new Federal Parliament

- NIEC institutional capacity improved and functional. long-term technical capacity of Somalia’s National Independent Electoral Commission (NIEC) developed. - On 26 August, MOIFAR organized a coordination session on the drafting process of the Electoral Law with key partners from the federal government, including the NIEC, representatives from the Office of the President as well as of the Prime Minister, a Member of the Parliament, MOCA, MOWAHR, and MOJ. - The lexicon has been finalized and is being printed for wider distribution. - Electoral process concluded as scheduled and the 10th Federal Parliament established

comment.narrative: 43% of Somalis live on less than $1/day, and 73% less than $2/day, unemployment stands at 48% and 80% of Somali households rely on natural resource-dependent activities for their livelihoods.

2. Long term employment fostered through provision of employable skills and local economic growth stimulated through grants to micro and small scale enterprises (Target-200 youth (60 women; 140 men) provided with market-based vocational skills training and startup capital/ toolkits to start new businesses or strengthen existing enterprises (The target group is the same target group in output 1: youth and women who have had access to social rehabilitation.)
3. Social and productive infrastructures rehabilitated (Target-6 infrastructures)
4. Knowledge of local authorities and communities on local level planning , monitoring and counter-piracy related issues improved (Target-Conduct training for the three district councils (Alula, Bargal and Balanbale) on local development planning and monitoring.Conduct awareness campaigns on the negative implications of piracy in the three targeted communities)

2. Training skills for 200 (60-women and 140-men) youths (70-Bargal, 70-Alula, and 60-Balanbale ) Completed and each trainee received a start kits grant of $500 . The only ongoing activity is the 60-Balanbale youths final sessions and anticipated to be completed in end of August 2016.
3. Construction/Rehabilitation of six infrastructures completed (1- Lafa-gorayo feeder road rehabilitation, construction of 2 Irish culvets in 1-Alula and 1-Habo, 1-Balanbale MCH construction , 2-Solar systems Installation ( 2KVA for Bargal Youth Center and 3.4 KVA for Balanbale MCH).The Very facilities have been successfully handed over to the Community and district administration
4. Local community training and anti-piracy campaigns for 40 participants (20 per district) were completed in Alula and Bargal districts while in Balanbale 30 participants received a session on piracy awareness whilst remaining sessions expected to complete in August 2016. The training objectives was to improve the Knowledge of local authorities and communities on local level planning, monitoring and counter-piracy related issues in the targeted districts
5. 200 youth (98 female and 102 male) completed skills training and social rehabilitation in the three target districts and has been completed.
6. All six target infrastructure are now completed – a feeder road, two Irish culverts in Alula and Bargal districts and a Youth Centre, Community Centre and a Mother and Child Health facility.
7. 30 - In Balanbale, two training session on piracy awareness session on piracy has been conducted for 30 participants including 8 women participants.

• Value chain development analysis of: (a) fishery, (b) dry fish export, (c) dairy, (d) sesame, completed; and the reports, with recommendations, developed • Along the fish value chain, 5 dry fish processing facilities constructed in Bossaso • 30 youth trained in fish production, processing, packaging and marketing, and engaged in dry fish businesses and made the constructed 5 dry fish processing facilities functional in Bossaso • The Ga’ate and Bulsho gravel roads (690m) that connects to the dry fish processing centres to markets, rehabilitated; and 150 youth got short term- job opportunity in Bosasso. • 1,440 short-term employments created for the drought-affected people (1,061 women) in both Somaliland and South West State • In response to drought, 3 water catchments, with a total capacity of 12,300 cubic m., built/rehabilitated, that benefitted 306 residents (50% women and girls) in 3 villages of Somaliland, who lost their livestock due to drought. • 985 short-term jobs created by improving sanitary condition of 51 new IDP camps in Baidoa. • 300 short-term jobs created (over 100 women) for debris cleaning in the aftermath of the devastated explosion in Mogadishu • 600 short-term jobs created (over 200 women) during the rehabilitation of public infrastructure in Mogadishu. • Two Programme Steering Committee meetings held in March and September 2017. Besides, the following coordination meetings on JP YES were held: (a) Donors and Implementing Partners meetings in March; (b) Technical Committee meeting in October; (c) Heads of Agencies meeting held in November 2017. • Three quarterly progress reports and one annual report developed, approved and shared with the Implementing Partners.

description.narrative: - Office of the focal point for charcoal programme in the Ministry of Livestock, Forest and Range (MOLFRD) strengthened - Number of briefings, workshops, coordination meetings held by the MOLFRD - First meeting of the International Charcoal Trade Regulatory Committee - Draft National and Regional Policy Document - International conference on Somalia Charcoal Reduction Programme held - Awareness raising workshops held in main towns and cities of Somalia - Programme Brochure, website and anti-charcoal campaign started - Funds mobilised from potential donors and development partners for the full-scale joint programme

comment.narrative: - Limited and dispersed capacities in the MOLFR - No capacity development or coordination activities carried out so far - No high-level forum exists to focus on charcoal issues and take policy level decisions - No National or Regional Policy Exist to reduce charcoal production, trade and use - No alliances or partnerships exist to support implementation of the Joint Programme - Low level of understanding on the possible actions to address charcoal issues - Masses are unaware of the Federal Government and UN Joint Efforts to curb charcoal trade and use - Available funds are not sufficient to implement the Joint Programme in its entirety

((Approved))

1. At least one region adopts a Quota 2. 150 Women political aspirants and candidates identified and supported 3. At least one Gender sensitive electoral policy/law

11 media stories and columns (against the target of 7) were published and featured on Geeska Africa Newsletter and several websites.
This target has also been fully met. 49 (27 from SL & 25 PL) young women recipients of UNDP GEWE tertiary scholarship have successfully completed their undergraduate programme.

1. Women Empowerment policy adopted in Puntland 2. Revised Provisional Federal Constitution includes gender perspectives. 3. GBV/Sexual offense laws are enacted in SL and FL 4. CEDAW ratification process reactivated

National Gender Policy for FGS. GEWE has approved agreement with the MWHRD and hired Gender advisor to support national consultations. In PL, women empowerment policy is being translated into Somali language.
A series of political changes following the election of new government in this quarter delayed the Review of the Provisional Federal Constitution. However, the process of nominating MPs to the constitutional oversight committee is ongoing Sexual Offence bill was approved in PL by the standing committee of parliament in this reporting period. SOB in SL has been tabled to the parliament for discussion and approval. FL SOB is being publicly consulted

1. Dedicated support was provided to RR on DSS 2. A programmatic framework was produced instead. See clarifications below* 3. This activity was cancelled due to bottlenecks beyond project's influence and resources redirected to drought response activities.
Draft Displacement Project Document
The most encouraged way of development programming in Somalia is “Joint Programmes”. It was found out at the very beginning of the assignment that there are a number of missing elements that would be necessary pre-conditions to even start outlining a JP on Displacement. These include: baseline dataset about the profile of displaced people and their places of abode; agreed upon guiding principles for response planning; institutional mechanisms at the national and the federal state levels for steering the durable solutions, and, a strategic framework to guide the process.
As a first step, building upon the ReDSS analysis, an Action Plan for Durable Solutions in Kismayo was compiled through a participatory process within the DSWG. The Action Plan was drafted and presented to the Government of Jubbaland and its endorsement is awaited. After the federal elections and the formation of the federal government, elements of the Action Plan were upscaled into a Partnership Strategy for Durable Solutions in Somalia, which achieved a number of important objectives, mainly: agreement in DSWG on Guiding Principles for Durable Solutions; agreement on adopting an area-based approach; using “displacement affected communities and locations” as the unit of analysis and planning; proposed institutional mechanism for governing the DS process at the national and federal states level, etc., An institutional quandary prevails at the federal level about the appropriate governmental counterpart for leading the DS process, with at least three entities –the National Commission on Refugees and IDPs, Prime Minister’s Office and Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs and Disaster Management- claiming it t
